an10.36:1.1: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to be attended on by a novice?”
an10.36:1.2: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to be attended on by a novice.
an10.36:1.4: It’s when a mendicant is ethical …
an10.36:1.6: Both monastic codes have been passed down to them in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, well judged in both the rules and accompanying material.
an10.36:1.7: They’re able to care for the sick or get someone else to do so.
an10.36:1.8: They’re able to settle dissatisfaction or get someone else to do so.
an10.36:1.9: They’re able to dispel remorse when it has come up.
an10.36:1.10: They’re able to rationally dissuade someone from misconceptions that come up.
an10.36:1.11: They’re able to encourage someone in the higher ethics,
an10.36:1.14: A mendicant should have these ten qualities to be attended on by a novice.”
